title: 110_hr254
content: The Act may be cited as the "David Ray Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2007" or "David's Law". Congress finds that violence motivated by race, color, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, gender, or disability disrupts communities, is divisive, and affects interstate commerce by impeding movement and access to goods and services. Violence motivated by bias that is a relic of slavery can constitute badges and incidents of slavery, warranting Federal intervention to assist jurisdictions lacking laws addressing such violence. Some States have laws that provide limited protection based on race, color, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, gender, or disability of the victim. The Act defines "hate crime" in alignment with the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. It also prohibits certain acts of violence. Section 245 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include harsher penalties for causing bodily injury based on race, color, religion, or national origin. The amendment allows for imprisonment up to 10 years, or life if death results from the crime. The amended Section 245 of title 18, United States Code, imposes harsh penalties for causing bodily injury based on religion, gender, sexual orientation, or disability. The penalties include imprisonment up to 10 years, or life if death results from the crime. The amended Section 245 of title 18, United States Code, imposes harsh penalties for acts involving kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder in connection with interstate or foreign commerce. The Federal Sentencing Commission will study adult recruitment of juveniles for hate crimes and may amend sentencing guidelines to enhance penalties for adult defendants who recruit juveniles. The Commission will ensure consistency with other guidelines and avoid duplicate punishments. Additionally, there is a grant program established. SEC. 6. GRANT PROGRAM. The Administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention will make grants to combat hate crimes by juveniles. Authorization of appropriations is provided. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION FOR ADDITIONAL PERSONNEL TO ASSIST STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. Appropriations are authorized to increase personnel to prevent and respond to hate crime violations.
